text:
I have an CGI based application, and we have probelms with Czech Chars in cgi
requests that are done as hypertext links, when the client is IE and the apache
server is running under Windows. 
When the link contains char with Czech transcription(Windows-CP1250 code page)
like a "r with caron" and convert it to "o" so the program cannot convert it
back, even it knows, that it is corrupted, because "o" is normal char.
This is only when we use the windows instalation of apache, the customers that
use apache on linux don't have this problem.
Thank you in advance, Tomas Krejzek
creator: respektive@post.cz
chip@force-elite.com
text:
Please check the Encoding that Apache is sending the in the HTTP headers.

I bet the Linux servers are likely using CP1250 or some other encoding that is
correct, while the Windows machine is not doing this.

Please loook at the documentation for mod_mime:
http://httpd.apache.org/docs-2.0/mod/mod_mime.html#addcharset

Also See mod_charset_lite:
http://httpd.apache.org/docs-2.0/mod/mod_mime.html#addcharset

This is a configuration issue, not a bug.

Thanks for using Apache.

creator: respektive@post.cz
text:
Thank You for Your answer, but I set WINDOWS-1250 as a default char set and add
it  in AddCharset section, so I think this is the right setup.

Apache 1.3.31 don't do this bug or configuration mismatch

Thank You
